fields.content:
This page allows you to browse MEPs according to the location of their offices in the EU Parliament buildings.

Note that MEPs meet around once a month in Strasbourg for a four-day part session from Monday to Thursday. The rest of the time, they can be contacted in their Brussels offices.
This page allows you to browse MEPs according to their score on the different votes monitored by La Quadrature du Net. To see the list of tracked votes, click here.

This page allows you to browse MEPs according to their score on the various votes monitored by La Quadrature du Net. For each resolution, directive or other dossier followed by La Quadrature, MEPs are graded according to how they vote.
This page allows you to see information on former MEPs.
What you are looking at right now is a currently work in progress version of the new design
fields.header: Welcome to the Political Memory of la Quadrature du Net

fields.content: This page allows you to browse MEPs sorted by their names.
This page allows you to browse MEPs sorted by their home Member States.

This page allows you to browse MEPs according to the political group they belong to in the EU Parliament. Every MEP belongs to a political group — they are not organised by nationality, but by political affiliation. There are currently 7 political groups in the European Parliament (souce)

This page allow you to browse MEPs according to the committee(s) they belong to. The committees of the EU Parliament draw up, amend and adopt legislative proposals and own-initiative reports. They consider EU Commission and ZU Council proposals and, where necessary, draw up reports to be presented to the plenary assembly. A committee consists of between 24 and 76 MEPs, and has a chair, a bureau and a secretariat. The political make-up of the committees reflects that of the plenary assembly (source).

This page allows you to browse MEPs according to the delegation they belong to. MEPs may take part in EU Parliament’s delegations on a voluntary basis. These delegations maintain and develop the European Parliament's international contacts, particularly relations with Parliaments in third countries (source).
This page allows you to browse MEPs according to the local party they belong to. Local parties refers to the national parties MEPs belong to in their home Member State.

This page allows you to browse MEPs according to the EU Parliament's  policital bodies they belong to. They organize the work on the EU  Parliament on a day-to-day basis, from legislative planning to  administrative tasks.
